instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.C7020: What is C7020? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for charger current sensing, you should measure around 20.02 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing as much power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.CHGR_BMON: What is CHGR_BMON? CHGR_BMON goes between the ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 that charges the battery & creates PPBUS_G3H and the SMC(system management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip) and provides current sensing information on battery charging to the SMC. If diagnostics reveal an off reading or failure with the charger current sense, this is a good place to start troubleshooting..
definitions.CHGR_AMON: What is CHGR_AMON? CHGR_AMON provides DC current sense information to the SMC(System management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip). It comes from the battery charging chip that controls the laptop charger, battery charging, and creation of PPBUS_G3H(ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip depending on the logic board part number and model). This is used for sensors. If a DC current sense sensor is reading off in diagnostics, this is a place to start looking. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
I have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that does not turn on.

Two USBC ports had different activity.
Port #1 =5v, 0.17A steady
Port#2 20v immediately cuts off, 0A then restarts

Found one drop of water on the board.  

That drop made corrosion at <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> near <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.  No water under <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.   Test point for PPVIN_G3HP3v3G3H was corroded away.  No continuity between <CAPACITOR>C7078</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C6991</CAPACITOR>.  Replaced resistors and made jumper to bring back continuity of PPVIN_G3HP3V3G3H
Also test point <SIGNAL>TBA_CSOR_N</SIGNAL> is corroded away, but this looks like it does not make an open when missing.

Result: Port#2 is now 20v and 0amp steady


I searched forum and read posts.   Learned that step one is make both usb c ports the same.
Diode mode of LDO rails showed a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL>.
Replaced only this <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>

NOW BOTH usbc ports are THE SAME
20v, 0.00A

Measured <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with no battery connected. Voltage= 1.1v declines to 0.95v and boosts to 1.1v, repeats pattern.

Diode mode on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.429

I stopped here to ask what would you do with this board next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
Post some <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> voltages; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>SMC_AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>CHGR_A</SIGNAL>/BMON.
Post ohm resistance over <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>/23 caps.

Try to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> =  20.56
<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> = 4.92
VDD/A = 3.01
VDD/B  = 5.11
<SIGNAL>SMC_AUX_OK</SIGNAL> =_3.41
<SIGNAL>CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL> = 3.4
<SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL> = 0
<CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR> 2.9
<CAPACITOR>C7023</CAPACITOR> 2.9
SMC BYPASS was unsuccessful for fan spin

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
I replaced earlier the two corroded resistors 7022 and <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> before I took the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area measurements and reported them here.
On inspection, I realize that <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> was not even--I must have nudged it during resistor replacement. I reballed it and returned it to the board.

Now Usbc port activity is 20v, 0.03A switching to 0A and back to 0.03A, or steady 0A

PPBUSG3H = 0.08v
PPBUSG3H diode mode =0.400
VDD/A = 1.09v
VDD/P is same 1.09v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
My preference would be to understand what <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> does so that I can troubleshoot on my own.
For example, I can see that <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> has power in from usbc charger, after it passes current sensing resistor <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>
I see CSIN and CSIP which are the two sides of the input current sensing circuit.

I see <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> which probably stands for something like auxiliary detection which must be when something other than a charger is plugged into usbc

SGATE and AGATE I recognize them as common in chips that control mosfets--I guess this is how the chip switches the mosfets

I don't know MPM Detection

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> seems like another power in

I see a couple of data lines where <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> talks to SMC

I see <SIGNAL>HPWR_EN_L</SIGNAL> which is an enable for <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, I'm not sure where it is from

CHGR AMON and BMON I recognize as common lines for charging chips but I don't know what they do.  I would like to know these lines.

There is an output <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> which probably tells the power management chip that usbc has been plugged in?

BGATE line probably goes with SGATE and AGATE to control the mosfets

CSOP and CSON are current sense circuits for the chip outputs?

Ultimately <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> talks to SMC and if it is told yes then it switches the mosfets to generate <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> from the DCIN and/or from the Battery, and it uses DCIN to charge the battery.  Is this right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 72123, member: 682"]

Are you saying the previous post has all correct values listed except for VDD/A?

What does VDD/A do?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
No datasheet available.
But you can compare with an old chip, like <CHIP>ISL6255</CHIP>/57; VDD/P described there.

I said to check <RESISTOR>R7075</RESISTOR>, take your time.
If good, then should get equal values in second post too.
You've got wrong voltages after reballed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
So chip is fried, or bad solders.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
Replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. 
Usb-c port "A" 20v .03a 
Usb-c port "B" restarts 
Relatively new OEM from Apple Store 96watt Macbook charger block stopped working.

Replaced two <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> with CD3215C0068AQ4CW from China
Both USB-C port status returned identical results. 5V 0.03a.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
Why did you change <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip where you've got 20V?
Put back that chip.
Possible bad new chips, or incorrect solders.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
"Why change a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> that is getting 20v"
Because before changing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, I had 20v on BOTH ports. 

Then I changed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and now the usbc ports have changed. 
Now one is 20v lowA and the other is restarting.

This means something happened with ELECTRICAL damage. I can not trust chips that I know have electrical damage.

It sounds like if 5v is on the ports this is <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> problem. I am posting here to see if that is true, or if there is something else to think about given the history of this case. I also am not sure if there is compatibility problems with <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> so I posted the whole number.

For example, in iPhone 5 tristar is A1608A1 and is not compatible with A1610A1, however A1610A1 can be swapped with A1610A2,A3 etc.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
C00 termination is what matters here.
If USB-C ports behaviour changed after replacing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, then should be corrosion problem.
One port is more affected than other.

Your previous post stated to have 5V on both ports...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
Scroll up--maybe I have been unclear?
My goal was to give as much history as possible.

[I]Copy/paste from above: I searched forum and read posts. Learned that step one is make both usb c ports the same.
Diode mode of LDO rails showed a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL>.
[B]Replaced only this <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>

NOW BOTH usbc ports are THE SAME
20v, 0.00A[/B][/I]

This was before I replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
After replacing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>

Usbc Master 20v 0A
Usbc Secondary restarting---this is the original condition.

Replaced BOTH because I must conclude there was electrical insult.

Now BOTH 5v with chinese <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>. CD3215C0068AQ4CW 

I will change <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> with stock from Louis and report back
[I] [/I]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
3215 replaced again.
USB port"A" back to 20v
USB port "B" shows 5v, 20v then restarts and repeats.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, no power
threads.message:
Usually board restarts when tries to boot and a problem is detected in a secondary power supply.
See what happens in SMC bypass.
Check for short on any big coil.
